sentence: Wall Street made a stronger start to the holiday-shortened trading week, with investors shrugging off last week's losses and geopolitical worries as telecoms and financials led gains.

Volumes were below average ahead of Thanksgiving on Thursday and a truncated session Friday, but a majority of the sectors on the S&P 500 ended in the green while the Dow Jones Industrial Average saw about two thirds of its blue chips rise, led by Verizon ( VZ ) and Home Depot ( HD ).
The Nasdaq Composite was slightly more subdued, constrained by losses in its health names.
Futures pointed to a weaker day in the US after German Chancellor Angela Merkel failed to form a government with political rivals.

But stocks were stronger with the opening bell in New York and mostly held on to the gains through the day, even as President Donald Trump decided to put North Korea back on the US list of state sponsors of terrorism.
Telecoms gained 1% in the strongest move among the S&P sectors as Verizon rose 1.7% after it was raised to outperform from market perform at Wells Fargo.

Health care stocks fell 0.4%, with Merck ( MRK ) among the top decliners on the Dow as it and Shire ( SHPG ) faced worries over rising competition for their drugs after rival Swiss drugmaker Roche reported positive late-stage trial results for two experimental drugs.
A thin economic calendar had just leading indicators rising 1.2% in October, better than the prior month's 0.1% and ahead of the consensus for 0.6%.
Markets absorbed with little impact the afternoon announcement from Fed Chair Janet Yellen that she will resign as member of the board of governors in February.

Here's where the markets stood by the close:

(+) EGLT (+1.49%) Secures InnoBooster grant to develop guardian technology outside of pain management

(-) LGND (-6.99%) Downgraded at Deutsche Bank to sell from hold

(-) GPOR (-4.89%) Downgraded at Barclays to equal weight from overweight

(-) LYV (-3%) Rating cut to in-line from outperform at Evercore

(-) PTR (-1.46%) Three workers killed, six injured in suspected gas leak
